<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>**Clarifying environment variables**

I'm focusing on the keys needed for the setup. First, in both the Vite client environment and the corresponding `.env` file, I need to define `VITE_SUPABASE_URL` and `VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY`. 

Second, for running migrations with Drizzle, I'll also need the `DATABASE_URL` for the Postgres connection. I noticed that the Supabase project credentials might expose `SUPABASE_DB_URL`, which could be relevant, so I'll check into that.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>**Summarizing environment variables**

I'm constructing a message for the user about environment variables for Supabase integration. For the front-end, they'll need a `.env` file with keys starting with VITE_, such as VITE_SUPABASE_URL and VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY. If they're using Drizzle or connecting to a production database, they'll want DATABASE_URL. Additionally, NODE_ENV and REPL_ID can be added, but they aren’t strictly necessary. I’ll also mention that for production, SUPABASE_SERVICE_ROLE_KEY may be considered, even though it hasn't been implemented yet.</details></think>

---

Here are the places in the codebase that look for environment variables and what each one is for.

1. Client-side (Vite) — required to run the React UI  
   • VITE_SUPABASE_URL → the “Project URL” you see in Supabase → Settings → API  
   • VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY → the “anon public” key from the same page  
   Put these two lines in `client/.env` (or export them in your shell) so the file looks like  

   ```
   VITE_SUPABASE_URL=https://<your-project>.supabase.co
   VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY=<copy-the-anon-key>
   ```

   They are read in `client/src/lib/supabase.ts`, and the app will throw “Missing Supabase environment variables” if either is absent.

2. Tooling / migrations (Drizzle CLI) — only needed if you plan to run database migrations yourself  
   • DATABASE_URL → a full Postgres connection string (e.g. `postgresql://user:pass@host:5432/db`)  
   Used in `drizzle.config.ts` when you run `drizzle-kit push` or similar.  
   The running server currently uses an in-memory store, so this variable is optional unless you want a real Postgres backend.

3. Dev convenience / Replit (optional)  
   • NODE_ENV and REPL_ID are checked in `vite.config.ts` to decide whether to load a Replit-specific plugin.  
     In local development you don’t need to set either one; Node sets `NODE_ENV=development` automatically and the plugin is skipped when `REPL_ID` is undefined.

That’s it—no other keys, secrets, or tokens are referenced anywhere in the project right now. Supplying the two Supabase values (and optionally `DATABASE_URL` for migrations) is enough to get everything running.
